captions.text:
DAVID HODGE: So what are we
going to be talking about

today is whether or
not numbers exist.

We're going to be thinking about
three different schools
of thought on this.

First one's Platonism, second
one's nominalism, and the last
one is fictionalism.

So mathematical Platonism takes
its lead from Plato,

obviously, as the
name suggests.

And the idea is that
numbers exist.
They really are things.
They're objects.

But they're abstract objects,
so they don't exist in the

same way that tables
and chairs do in
space and in time.

Numbers exist outside
space, outside time.

They don't cause other
things to happen.

They're totally abstract
objects.

One of the reasons that people
like mathematical Platonism is

that we think that a lot of
claims about numbers in
mathematics are true.

Right, so certainly I think
that things that
mathematicians say are true.

I think that's a good
starting point.

But they say things like
there's a number
between 6 and 8.

That seems like it's a true
thing, it's the number 7.

And Platonists think that that
means that there must exist an

object that is the number 7,
even if it's not an object
that you can touch.

And they appeal to kind of
similar reasoning about the

way that we speak about
the ordinary,
kind of concrete world.

So if I say to you that there's
a nose between two

eyes, that nose had better exist
for what I say to be
true, right?

If there's no nose here, then
what I've said is false.

So in the same kind of way,
right, if there's a number

between six and eight, that
thing had better exist.

Platonists aren't happy to use a
loose sense of "exist" here,

so they think that exists
just means exists.

And so in the same way that a
table exists, a chair exists,
a number exists.

All the numbers exist,
in fact.

It just so happens that
they're not located
in space and time.

So it's a difference about
location, rather than whether

or not they exist, or whether
they exist in a
different kind of way.

All sorts of fun problems
with the view.

The first of which that you come
across, particularly when

you start teaching this stuff,
is that's crazy.

So numbers exist outside
space and time?

What does that even
mean, right?

It's really, really hard to kind
of get your head around.

But we can be a bit more refined
than that when we're

objecting to mathematical
Platonism.

So one of the things that we
said was that mathematical

claims are true, but that
mathematical claims are

actually claims about these
abstract objects.

These abstract objects don't
causally interact with us
because they're abstract.

OK, but we think that
mathematicians
are massively reliable.

So what they say, pretty much
guaranteed to be true.

If their claims are actually
about these abstract objects,

then it looks like we need some
explanation of how those

mathematicians so reliably
track that
world of abstract objects.

So if a mathematician tells you
that 6 times 7 is 42, then
what he's saying is true.
What they're saying is true.

How is it that they're so
reliably managing to access

this world of abstract
objects?

Answering that question's
really hard for the

Platonists, because they just
don't think we can interact
with that world.

Our second theory is
mathematical nominalism.

So what the nominalist
wants to do is
agree with the Platonist.

That all of our mathematical
claims are true, but that our

mathematical claims should best
be understood as claims
about objects in the world.

So tables, chairs, pencils,
those kinds of things.

And to get a kind of bit of
intuition on this kind of

thing, often helps to think
about the way you might teach
a child to count.

So children don't tend to be
born with these kind of
abstract principles.

One, two, three, four,
five, six, and so on.

What we tend to do is to say,
like, here's a pencil.
Here's another.
Now you've got two pencils.

And it seems that what we do
when we learn to count is we

count with respect to a
particular type of objects, or
to objects in general.

And what the nominalist says is,
well, that's all there is
to number talk, right?

What you mean when you say 6
times 7 is 42 is that if you

had 6 lots of 7 objects,
you'd have 42 objects.

That's what mathematics
is about.

It's about concrete things
in the world.

This kind of nominalist view
begins to run into trouble

when we start to think about
more complicated numbers or
numerical concepts.

So if we start to think about
the square root of minus 1,

for instance, and the imaginary
numbers and so on.

So it's really easy to say 2
plus 2 equals 4 is about these

2 objects and those 2 objects,
and there being 4 objects.

Much harder to see what object
or thing might be the square
root of minus 1.

So if you're a mathematical
Platonist, it's really easy.

It's just another number,
just like all the rest.

But if you're a nominalist,
what's the
thing that it's about?

Looks really, really hard to see
what that's going to be.

So pi is also similarly
complex, right?

So if you're a nominalist, it
looks like you're going to

think that numerical
talk is just talk
about concrete things.

But of course, pi doesn't seem
to have a precise value, or at

least we certainly can't
calculate that value.

So there's a real question
for the nominalist here.

How are you going to understand
pi as a thing, or a

collection of things, when
we can't ever get to that
terminating value?

Our third group in the
philosophy of mathematics is
the mathematical fictionalist.

So I said at the start that I
think it's a good thing to say

that what mathematicians
say is true.

And the fictionalist doesn't
quite agree.

So the fictionalist says,
actually, mathematical
discourse is false.

It's really useful, really
helpful, but it's
systematically just false.

That's quite an extreme view to
take, given the success of

science within which mathematics
is embedded, but

that's the view that
the mathematical
fictionalist takes.

So the fictionalist says numbers
don't exist, whereas

the Platonist says numbers are
these existing abstract

objects, and the nominalist says
mathematical discourse is

about concrete objects
in the world.

The fictionalist says it's
not about anything.

It's just a useful story that
we've developed to help
ourselves get on in the world.

BRADY HARAN: But surely the
mathematical fictionalist uses

modern communications, is
dependent on satellites.

How do they explain
those things?

Because obviously they
use numbers.

How do they explain that they're
using something that
they say doesn't exist?

DAVID HODGE: So what the
fictionalist has got to do is

try and explain away the success
of mathematics and the
success of science.

But without saying that
mathematical claims are true.

And one strategy that the
fictionalist can deploy around

here is to say that success in
the world isn't a hallmark of

truth, or needn't be a
hallmark of truth.

We were talking about modern
communications, technology

relying on all of this
mathematics.

What the fictionalist will say
is what that indicates is that
the mathematics is successful.

It doesn't indicate
that it's true.

If it was true, says the
fictionalist, these

mathematical objects, these
platonic objects that the

mathematical Platonist thinks
exist, those things
would have to exist.
But they don't.

And so in fact, our
mathematical
discourse can't be true.

It can at best be a
useful fiction.

There are appeals that they can
make around here that kind

of help bring out the sort
of thing that they
might want to do.

Imagine that you thought that
the Bible was a work of
fiction, for instance.

Some people do, some
people don't.

But you might think it codifies
a really useful set
of moral principles.

And you might think that there's
no such thing as truth
and morality.

But you might think as guiding
principles go, these are
pretty helpful.

They help us get on
in the world.
Don't kill other people.

Help societies develop, which
helps us develop in
interesting kinds of ways.

The mathematical fictionalist
might say very similar things

about the language
of mathematics.

Helps us get on, but that it
helps us to get on doesn't
mean that it's true.

BRADY HARAN: Where do you
stand on all this?

You've very neutrally given
me the three positions.

Is there one that resonates
with you?

DAVID HODGE: So the view that
resonates with me the most, I

guess, is mathematical
nominalism.

So I don't think that there
are abstract objects.

I don't think that there
are numbers.

I think that it's too much of
a stretch to think that
mathematics is false.

My colleagues in the math
department will, I'm sure, be
delighted by this.

So I adopt the middle ground,
what I take to be the middle

ground, anyway, which is
a kind of mathematical
nominalism.

BRADY HARAN: You were telling
me that the nominalist runs

into problems with some of
these more spectacular
irrational numbers.

Do you run into problem
with those numbers?

DAVID HODGE: Yes, that means
that I inherit all of the

problems that the mathematical
nominalist faces.

The kind of move that I like
to make around here with

respect to pi is to say that
whenever we actually calculate

with it, when we're using it
mechanically, if you like,

what we're doing is we're using
a best approximation.

Now, that's a spectacularly
accurate, well, it's a

spectacularly long
approximation, anyway.

I really shouldn't say it's
accurate, because I don't

think it maps to a
platonic ideal.

But it's a spectacularly long
and very useful approximation.

But I don't think there's
anything other than that
endless sequence, I guess.

And of course, you can derive
that perfectly acceptably.

I think the reason that
philosophers get into the

philosophy of mathematics, one
of the reasons, anyway, is

precisely because there
are so many things to
philosophize about.

It's another thing for us
to get excited about and
interested in.

The grand tradition of thinking
about numbers, it

goes right back to
Plato, hence the
mathematical Platonism.

And so people just get excited
and interested in it, I think.

comments.text:
This is a nonsensical question.

Math is the language, which we use to describe, analyze and study patterns, 
whether they occur in nature (science) or pertain to purely abstract 
concepts (what we usually call 'mathematics').

And numbers are merely a part (probably the oldest) of that language's 
vocabulary, born out of the need to describe quantities.

So they do or do not exist in the same way, that words do or do not exist.﻿

Personally, I believe that numbers as a type of tool. They CAN be used for 
describing objects, but not necessarily. They aren't in themselves objects.

They began as a construct to aid in communication (this is how many sheep I 
have), then a construct formed to aid in the communication of addition and 
subtraction (I need three more sheep). Eventually, it broke into a field 
where they are used for many purposes. However, the field of mathematics 
and numbers is simply a field created by humans.﻿

comments.author: Shadowfly

comments.text:
I don't think fictionalism needs to be as extreme in saying numbers don't 
exist, but rather they are tools for understanding the universe. A lot of 
the mathematics in science seem to be measurements i.e. seconds or meters 
or kilograms. But were all these measurements not manmade constructs? We 
compare all lengths to a meter or kilometer, but where did they come from? 
They could be just a random interval someone decided upon. Kilograms and 
other mass measurements are the same. Time might be different, since it 
seems to be based around how long it takes for the earth to orbit the sun, 
but there is no reason why a second couldn't be twice as long and there 
were only 30 in a minute. A lot of the measurements we use for mathematics 
are baseless and were standardised for convenience. Its a bit of leap to 
apply the same logic to numbers in general, but we created these 
measurements as tools for understanding the universe. Could numbers be 
considered similarly? Are science and fictionalism even mutually exclusive?﻿
comments.author: Zach Wilkinson

comments.text:
Mathematics is a language. It is a collection of concepts that are meant to 
reflect reality. Mathematics are in their most base form- the adjectives in 
which we define are world. Mathematics are no different than language, or 
letters. If we, as a global society, decided to give the symbol 7 the value 
of 5,  and vica versa, 7 would then be 5. However, assuming that those two 
were the only two that changed, than the statement 3(7)=15 wold become 
true. Furthermore, just as any language has rules on how certain letters, 
and cretin words may be combined, so does mathematics (see dividing by 
zero, and imaginary numbers)﻿

comments.text:
Can I take both Platonism and Fictionalism at the same time? Let me explain.
I think maths is the most pure and thus most abstract study of 
relationships, ratios and descriptions. The universe seems to be based on 
relationships, ratios and descriptions, in fact that's all the universe 
seems to be, so with that you could argue for Platonism, however, modern 
maths is *our way of representing these relationships, ratios and 
descriptions in ways that we can understand them*, which means in that 
sense, it is not pure, and thus human-thought-based so with that you could 
argue fictionalism. That brings me to the conclusion that it is 
fictionalism in that it has a human form and it is Platonism in that it is 
what seems to be in unity with the fundamental processes behind all things 
in our observable universe (we just haven't got to the "grand equation that 
describes/predicts everything in our universe" yet).﻿

comments.author: MrNateSPF

comments.text:
I always thought of math like abstract representations of all the logically 
possible and therefore necessarily valid  relations and interrelations. 
Which would mean that in terms of logic, mathematical truths are about how 
things can relate to one another and not about the things themselves. The 
"truth" of mathematics denote logically valid relational possibilities, 
regardless of the objects which are in relation, that is a mathematical 
truth is the truth of a relation, not of a "thing". That is, maths conveys 
true relational features about any possible "objects" as long as they are 
in relationship with each other (or themselves A=A), and this includes 
objects which ontologically (physically) do not exist, that is, all 
relational properties which exist in the real universe are mathematical 
truths (they have their pure models in math), but not all mathematical 
relations have to exist or exist in the real world: the realm of all the 
possible relations in greater than the realm of actual relations between 
actually existing things. Furthermore, the validity of relational states of 
affairs does not depend on the ontological status of the objects it applies 
to. One dragon and one dragon seen through the relationship of an aggregate 
will be two dragons, despite dragons being merely fictional entities, their 
"twoness" (their possibility of being in this relation) is just as solid as 
in the case of chairs or planets.﻿

comments.text:
Frankly, I think Plato was daft for his theory of Forms which then spawned 
the idea that numbers are "real" things in some netherworld outside 
spacetime. But fictionalists are no less daft for their insistence that 
numbers are just a useful fiction. For numbers to be at all useful they 
must be at least a close representation of reality. How could anybody with 
even the slightest capacity for reason see six groups of seven objects and 
not think they really add up to forty-two? To me, fictionalists sound like 
a bunch of stoners postulating any sort of goofiness their drug-addled 
minds can concoct. Nominalism is the only rational view.﻿

comments.author: Benjamin Márkus

comments.text:
My idea of mathematics is that they can never be completely applied to real 
life. Mathematics is an abstract concept which can be applied to a finite 
extent to real life, which helps us with everything we have. Concepts like 
"on" and "off" give us binary, and counting your apples will give you an 
abstract representation. 

However, if you want to measure the diameter of this apple, you will have 
an infinitely long (real but irrational) number that can never be written 
out completely or be represented in any type of number system. This applies 
to measurements of any kind. 

Therefore, I would argue that maths is an abstract concept that humans have 
come up with in the abundance of patterns in the world, which has helped us 
and will continue to help us.﻿

comments.text:
Numbers are equivalence classes of sets, under equinumerosity. Hence the 
existence of a universe of sets is a sufficient condition for the existence 
of numbers. Finite numbers exist if the empty set exists. The existence of 
alpha-null has to be postulated. Category theory requires the 
Tarski-Grothendieck axiom.﻿
comments.author: alnot01

comments.text:
It seems like there should be a fourth line of thought; something of a 
counterpoint to fictionalism.  Numbers don't tangibly exist; they're merely 
concepts that we have grown to understand.  The relationships between the 
points in this number system can be defined as mathematics, and the fact 
that our technologies work should be a testament to the truth of 
mathematics, not it's falsity.  Fictionalism confuses empiricism with 
conceptuality.  In other words, just because I can't hand you something 
that is the number 5, doesn't mean that all of mathematics is false.  That 
would be as absurd as saying air doesn't exist because I can't see it.﻿

comments.text:
I believe that every theory can fail in some way. Mathematics is just a way 
to transport ideas between different theories, so that an idea can be used 
again and again. That means that, since even mathematics is a theory, it 
will become infinitely complex as soon as you try to relate it to reality.

As simple as math can be, theories that are complex can also become simple 
if you stop understanding them. It is a bit like reading a history book and 
remembering every detail, it can be frustrating.

I think I have put much time into understanding mathematics, thinking that 
the world is mathematical in nature. The more complex the world becomes in 
my mind, the more it becomes a chaos theory. And that's because we are 
using the tools of logic to produce complex theories, which in themselves 
are not tautologies, or logical.

I guess that since the world is a statement, it is not a tautology. 
Therefore there is not an equation of the universe.﻿

comments.text:
+ToXeye Someone once told me to stay away from tautologies. I once thought 
that tautologies were the stuff of logic, that which defines the universe. 
I guess I just liked tautologies. But tautologies are different in language 
than in math. For example, if someone reads this and thinks "what I'm 
reading here is obvious" then I am writing a tautology. I think that 
numbering things is a good way of keeping them apart, and counting them is 
a good way of confusing them so numbers are not useless after all. But

comments.text:
Hey Numberphile, I really enjoyed this video for many reasons. Firstly, I 
love how you delve into a topic that nobody ever really thinks about. I 
know in my math class, Honors Pre Calc, we try to understand where our 
formulas come from and understand what they mean and how they help us solve 
problems. This has led to a few of my classmates to ask, "Why is this 
important?" or "What's the point of this?" with a legitimate want for a 
response. My teacher usually provides them with solid answers along the 
lines of "This is a thinking class as well as a math class." Secondly, I 
like how the information was presented in an objective manner while also 
being incredibly entertaining. Lastly, I liked how at the end of the video, 
I was able to pick a stance (I'm a Platonist) and feel empowered by it. 

Whenever I've thought about math in the past, I never really questioned the 
existence of numbers. After watching this video it occurred to me that this 
thought is incredibly polarizing, so much so that it has created 3 
subdivisions of opinions. I am slightly confused on the opinion of the 
nominalist outside of whole numbers. It just seems odd to define difficult 
equations and complex numbers in the real world, but I still respect their 
opinion. The way that you described Platonism seems like the strongest of 
the three sides. Getting back to the purpose of this video, I was inspired 
by you guys taking on the task of making a video about a concept nobody 
really seems to talk about. This video should definitely be shown to any 
student or mathematician who is having an "existential" crisis about why 
they are doing math. 

You guys did a great job being objective in the way you presented the 
information. Being a nominalist yourself, it must have been challenging to 
derive a way to elaborate on the other two philosophies without poking 
holes in their arguments. This was really an awesome video that transcends 
a lot of boundaries in our world. Anybody can do math, and anybody can have 
their own opinion on the concepts of math.

Finally, this video gave me something I didn't have before I watched it, an 
educated opinion on the topic. I can honestly say I had no leaning when it 
came to whether or not numbers actually existed before this video, but 
after it, I can say with confidence, that I am a Platonist. So this is a 
big thank you, Numberphile, you guys did an outstanding job with this 
video. You've empowered me, the viewer, to see numbers in a completely 
different way. ﻿

+Oliver Chen "j^2 = 1, but j is not 1". Using DeMoivre's formula: (cosx + 
isinx)^n = cos(nx) + isin(nx), it is easy to see that the only possible 
values for j are e^(theta*i), where theta = 0 (mod pi). This yields ONLY 
two values for j: -1 and 1. 
And thus, to summarize, you were incorrect when you said that "the point is 
that j is its own type of imaginary number" because there is no point on 
the complex plane where j exists.
Even if we extend into 4 dimensions (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quaternion), 
your j does not exist just because the 2nd, 3rd and 4th dimensions are 
based off of the square root of -1.

i'm a biologist, but i know a little bit of physics and i think of it in 
this way: sinusoidal waves depend on circles and pi and all that jazz. a 
wave (which we can observe in nature in the form of light or sound or 
vibrations or oscillations) has a wavelength/frequency, which are related 
to energy (energy = planck's constant * frequency (a property directly 
related to wavelength). however, the uncertainty principle in physics 
dictates that there is a time-energy uncertainty relation, so the only way 
we can know a wavelength with absolute precision is to observe it for an 
infinitely long duration of time (roughly speaking) which is impossible; 
this is why measuring a perfect circle by extension is impossible. but the 
nature 'behind' the uncertainty follows mathematical laws where waves 
interfere to cause the uncertainty. this means that these waves really 
could be governed by what you might call the platonic circle. perhaps 
someone could correct me or explain if i'm reasoning incorrectly.

Lets say I build a missile. And I want to hit a target on the other side of 
the world with that missile with accuracy. I would need the missile's 
guidance system to interact with GPS satellites in order to hit that 
target. The computers in the missile and the satellite are programmed using 
our understanding of "math". You could pin point any location on earth with 
coordinates. If I were to invent a coordinate system that mapped out the 
earth, that doesn't use numbers, but random symbols. Then I  program a 
computer that understands those symbols, which in turn build a satellite 
and a missile that runs on that computer. Could I hit a target anywhere on 
earth with that missile? If so, what does that say about numbers. If 
numbers are truly real, would that missile not work?﻿

comments.text:
No, your missile, using only symbols, would completely miss the target. 
Because the relations between numbers, and the continuity of space, are 
needed in order to chart the path the missile takes from the launcher to 
the target. The end coordinates are not enough. Renaming only the end 
coordinates doesn't allow you to rebuild the entire path.

Even if you have all the coordinates along the paths, you also need the 
direction, in order to control the missile's navigations, since a missile 
doesn't just move arbitrarily, it moves with momentum and inertia.

If you rename every point along the path, and all the directions, then 
you've essentially constructed the real line, and given it relations 
roughly equivalent to continuity and derivation. In other words, you've 
simply renamed numbers. You're back to numbers, with all of their original 
mathematical meaning.

comments.text:
Hear hear.

I'm perfectly comfortable with the idea that numbers might be pure fiction 
and yet mathematics is completely real and works.

numbers being imaginary != maths is somehow false.

It's like we learned the mathematical rules by thinking about how to deal 
with real, platonic things (like how many chickens should be traded and for 
how much money?), but as the rules got more generalised we've been able to 
break-free of the confines of platonic objects (like "i" or "e").

"e" is a good example actually. It's a representation of some completely 
natural behaviour (we didn't invent growth), which is certainly real, but 
not really platonic, i.e., you can't "hold" natural growth in your hands.

I think the question itself is un-answerable to be honest. It's a very deep 
question and requires a solid definition of "real". I mean, how do we know 
that anything is real? (The Matrix is such a fun movie because of the 
difficulty in this question), so asking this question on something as 
abstract as numbers should be met with honest agnosticism (it seems to me). 
I'm totally comfortable with that :)

comments.text:
I would say (natural) numbers explain certain relations between sets. If I 
have 3 apples here and you have 3 bananas there, there is something your 
banana's have in common with my apples. And that is that they have the same 
number. Another way to put it would be, if you have 2 sets you define a 
number as a equivalence relation between those sets.

 If you can get a 1-1 correspondence between those sets they have the same 
number of elements in them. If you can't assign to every member of set B a 
unique member of set A set B is bigger than set A. So there is an order. 
Then you can see a natural number as an equivalence class of sets defined 
by the above equivalence relation.﻿

I can't make a triangle. A triangle's edges have no width -- no physical 
substance. I can make a triangle in my imagination. Triangles are 
imaginary. They exist is a concept space. All concepts "reside" in concept 
space. The concept of a perfect circle is there. The concept of a concept 
is there. Self-concepts are there. Your concept of me is there and mine of 
you, dear reader. (Are concepts real?)

being being human; interacting with other human beings and the environment

behaves statistically predictably. From qm to romance statistical 
predictability. ﻿

comments.text:
I don't think there's anything wrong with nominalism just because imaginary 
and negative numbers can't describe quantities of real objects. All we have 
to know is that numbers correspond with physical realities that we can 
verify — and they do. I.e., equations that we rely on to determine and 
describe how the world works, do so, despite using numbers that are 
negative, imaginary, irrational, etc. That doesn't mean that every number 
has to correspond with a quantity of physical objects. All we have to know 
is that they *could*. If you could have a negative amount of objects, then 
negative numbers would correspond to physical objects just as surely as 
positive numbers do. The fact that negative quantities of physical objects 
don't exist is a limit on physical reality, not on the realness of numbers. 
You may not be able to create pi apples because pi is irrational, but *if** 
you could have pi apples, pi would describe that quantity of apples*. 
Numbers are only concepts — but they're *real* concepts. So I guess I'm a 
Platonist-nominalist. Which brings me to my other big beef about this 
argument, which is that it's a false trichotomy. It makes me so mad when 
people present differing views or models or perspectives as if they are 
mutually exclusive and are the only options. I especially hate it in 
psychology; but really, I hate it in any area.﻿

comments.text:
Not exactly a neutral characterization of platonism, which holds not just 
for abstract objects such as numbers but also of uninstantiated properties. 
Epistemological concerns such as those posed by the Benacerraf Dilemma 
typically arise from a causal theory of knowledge, which presupposes a kind 
of empiricsm that is already incompatible with platonism and its 
rationalist epistemology. The two schools of nominalism and platonism here 
are just talking past each other, rather than offering decisive objections.﻿

comments.text:
Your example about Platonism and negative one is faulty. The ancient Greeks 
had a fear of the void and the infinite, and thus denied the existence of 
both zero and infinity (ever wondered why our counting system starts with 
one, not zero?). Thus they also denied the existence of negative numbers, 
as admitting to them would be admitting to zero. Which is also why Zeno's 
paradox gave them so much trouble.﻿

Numbers and ratios come into existence with the birth of human thinking and 
the invention of the means of quantification and counting. Natural numbers 
are an abstract concept of a property of sets of things that have been 
conceptually combined to belong to a common category. Just as you can think 
about the number of objects in a particular set you can reason about the 
concept of numbers itself. So numbers can become an object of thinking and 
so "exist" - but as an abstract concept.
Nevertheless, they cannot "exist" unless you are able to categorise things 
and categorisation (which is a result of abstraction) is a basis of 
thinking. Even when counting your fingers you need to know about the 
concept of what are fingers.
Real numbers come up when you firstly extend this concept to uncountable 
(but measurable) variables and then extend it to a formalism of ratios that 
can not be measured exactly.﻿

if and when in complies with observations, and there is no simpler theory 
that will yield the same predictions. Using this definition all rational 
numbers nominally exist, whereas so-called “real numbers” actually do not 
exist. (we do not need them for any prediction, just a very good 
approximation of what they are supposed to be.)﻿
comments.author: Peter Velzen

comments.text:

comments.author: Taavi Viikman

comments.text:
How about nothing but numbers exist? Basically, every particle has its 
values, its location, its properties etc. All the numbers we make up are 
ways to connect those values. Numbers don't exist in the sense of 1, 2, 3 
but as relations. So this is twice that, and this is 3 times that and so 
on. The complex numbers like phi are simply infinitely long connections.

In the end, if we'd take away the human interpretation of the universe, 
it's all just trillions times trillions times trillions times trillions of 
data points with interaction with one another.

Just my view on the topic, be welcome to share your thought.﻿
comments.author: debries

comments.text: Yes that is the mathematical universe idea.

comments.text:
Yeah. Its possible. I used to think of it like that too. However I remember 
seeing an experiment once involving converging light beams that seemed to 
indicate the universe was flat. I'll have to look into that again though as

I think our very existance points toward infinity though. The odds of life

an infinite universe however its a certainty.

comments.text:

Why would the earth moving around in empty space blow my mind? It not a 
hard concept to grasp. As for the big bang, i wont pretend i know exactly 
what happened but the idea sits comfortably with me. A finite universe 
however is nonsense. If the universe has and end what would happen if i

comments.author: George Steele

comments.text:
I actually agree with you. My own personal theory is that all of reality is 
in fact a quantum bit. And by that I mean a piece of information that 
equals both zero and one at the same time (not that I consider time to even 
exist at this point, I just used it for lack of a better word). So 
ultimately this means that all combinations of the two must exist making 
all of reality just a product of infinity.

First thing people ask me when I try to explain this is usually "How do you 
get from numbers to physical things?" and I tell them to look at a 3D game. 
You can see that you are playing within a world of seemingly solid objects 
but at the end of the day you could take the machine code, convert it to 
decimal and what your left with is a number. A number that contains all the 
information needed to create a 3D world. If you think of just enormous 
infinity actually is would it be any surprise that somewhere in there is 
the code for Earth and the rest of the universe?
comments.author: Devilofdoom

comments.text:
+Pseudo Arch Because theorizing is just that, theorizing. I might be 
fundamentally wrong, but it is just a theory. Unless you have strong 
reasons/proofs of me being wrong, it will be a theory.

Also, just because we are humans doesnt mean we cant think or theorize 
about things beyond the human ways, even though we cant fully comprehend 
it. If I get data on a piece of paper and I know enough formula's, I could 
do massive calculations on everything without ever needing to see what 
exactly I'm calculating. So up to a point, the universe is just raw data 
that changes itself (in a way, just not sure what to think of quantum 
physics in this)
